                      Executive Summary

           Royster-Clark Nitrogen - Marseilles, IL

                              

A.   Introduction:



The  Royster-Clark Nitrogen terminal in Marseilles  receives

fertilizers from barges, stores the fertilizer in tanks, and

loads trucks.  The facility has two anhydrous ammonia tanks

and four  urea  ammonium  nitrate (UAN) liquid  fertilizer

storage tanks.  In addition there are two dry warehouses and

a dry barge unloading facility.





B.  Accidental Release Record:



The Royster-Clark Nitrogen, Marseilles Terminal, has an

excellent safety record with no deaths or serious injuries

to facility personnel since it was constructed in 1964.



The facility safety record is the direct result of continued

emphasis on safety by management, employees, contractors,

and truck drivers.

There have not been any releases from the terminal that meet

the description of an RMP accidental release.



In case of a reportable chemical accident, information in

the RMP will be updated within six (6) months of the date

accident accrued.



C. General Accidental Release Prevention Policies And



   Activities:

Royster-Clark Nitrogen believes safety and concern for the

environment must be second nature to all employees and

contractor personnel.

The entire Royster-Clark Nitrogen team works together to

ensure the facility is in compliance with OSHA's Process

Safety Management standards and the accident prevention

programs are continuously improved.  A networked computer

management system is utilized to provide our employees with

the necessary tools and records to maintain the safety of

the process. This teamwork is an integral part in the safety

efforts of this facility. Accident release prevention steps

include the fourteen element program for Process Safety

Management, a management system, corporate oversight of the

facility, and a focus on

continuous improvement.

Royster-Clark Ni

trogen encourages all employees to

participate in the facility's safety program. Examples of

employee participation include participation in Process

Hazard Analyses, cooperative training, updating of operating

procedures, and emergency response activities.





Royster-Clark Nitrogen has well established practices and

procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems,

relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, compressors, and

emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.

This program includes:





 1.   training

 2.   written operating procedures

  3.   inspections and tests in accordance with recognized

       standards. 4.   correction of deficiencies, and

 5.   quality assurance



In combination, these activities form a system that

maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.

Maintenance personnel receive training on  (1) an overview

of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) emergency

response plans, and (4) applicable safe work practices to

help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe

manner.  Written procedures help ensure that work is

performed in a consistent manner, conforms to generally

accepted standards, and provides a basis for training.

Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that

equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment

is within acceptable limits Royster-Clark Nitrogen has a

comprehensive system to manage changes to processes.  This

system requires that changes to items such as process

equipment, chemicals, technology, procedures, and other

facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before

being implemented.



D.   Worst Case Scenario:

This information was removed from the executive summary in

accordance with (40 CFR 68.190 (b)(6).















E.  Anhydrous Ammonia Alternative Scenario:



The alternative release scenario resulting in the greatest

off site consequences  would involve a release of hot

anhydrous ammonia from

an ammonia flash drum  under elevated

temperatures and pressures as a result of over filling the

vessel at a maximum pressure and volume of ammonia in the

system.



F.  Five Year Accident History:



The Royster-Clark Nitrogen Marseilles Terminal has an

excellent safety record with no deaths or serious injuries

to any of its personnel.  In addition, the terminal has

operated without a lost time accident for over seventeen

years.



There  have  not been any incidents that meet the definition

of a RMP recordable release.



G.  Emergency Response:



The facility Emergency Action Plan covers accidental

releases of plant chemicals, natural disasters, emergency

response practices and procedures, and process safety

topics. The plan is reviewed at least annually with all

employees.



All  permanent  employees  have  the required Hazmat

training, including an eight-hour refresher course annually.

Each  employee and permanent contractor is trained on the

facility's  Emergency Response policies and procedures  at

regularly scheduled plant safety meetings.

The  terminal manager and his assistant attend monthly

Community Advisory Panel meetings. This panel includes other

area industries, Marseilles Village board members, local

emergency response agencies, community leaders,and citizens.



The Emergency Response Plan is followed in the event of an

  emergency. The emergency alarm system is tested once each

  month and an emergency drill is held at lease annually.

Updates to the Emergency contact information will be

  reported within one (1) month of change.









H.   Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



The Royster-Clark  Nitrogen Marseilles Terminal will utilize

employee input and industry best management practices to

continuously improve safety, environmental, and all

operations.



I.  Summary:



The Royster-Clark Nitrogen Marseilles Terminal and its

employees are extremely proud of its safety record and the

vast improvements in both s

afety and environmental.  We

believe that with the programs and policies in place in our

terminal and the continued

efforts of 100% of our personnel, we will be able to

maintain our safety record and a safe plant environment for

all concerned in the years ahead.
